**Living Apart Together Is a Growing Trend-But Should You Be Doing It?**

**Benefits of Living Apart Together**

Living apart together, also known as LAT, is a growing trend for couples who want to continue their relationship but not in the same household. Choosing to live apart together is a deliberate decision where both partners are committed to each other but prefer to maintain separate living spaces.

*   Couples who prefer LAT like maintaining their routines and having personal space as they value their freedom and independence.
*   It allows each partner to manage their own living environment while enjoying the emotional and physical intimacy of a committed relationship.
*   The Relationship Doesn't Get Boring
    *   People participate in the LAT model because it keeps the relationship new and fresh.
    *   Many people get tired of their partners and feel less excited about them when they're together all the time.
*   Some Partners Have Their Preferences and Quirks-Which Is OK
    *   This relationship model is also a fit for other situations, too.
    *   For example, your job is miles apart from your partner's home and you don't want a long commute to the office.

**Challenges of Living Apart Together**

Of course, the benefits of LAT come with a few challenges, namely social stigma, communication, and emotional distance.

*   Social Stigma
    *   People may ask them why they're not living together or when they're moving in together.
    *   Suggest that their relationship must be struggling because they're not living together.
*   Difficulty Finding Time Together Outside of social stigma, one of the biggest challenges of living apart in relationships is schedule coordination and communication.

**Making LAT Work**

It takes some work to create a successful LAT relationship-any relationship, really-but it's completely possible. One first step is planning quality time, so the relationship stays connected.

*   Planning dates ahead of time and sending spontaneous text messages (so they know you're thinking of them) are just a few small things to make your partner feel seen and appreciated.
*   To prevent conflict avoidance, Reed recommends establishing communication and conflict rules on how arguments and discussions will be handled.

**Considerations for Choosing LAT**

The first way to know if LAT is for you is if you, like me, wanted to live with partners in the past but disliked it. Think of past conflicts you've had in relationships and reflect on how many of them were related to sharing a living space, suggests Weiss.

*   Consider your personal values, lifestyle preferences, and relationship intentionality when deciding to opt in or out of a LAT relationship.
*   Also, consider the social stigma attached to LAT aka the belief that not living together implies a lack of commitment. If LAT relationships were more normalized, many relationships may actually last longer because the people in them would be less annoyed with each other and would have an easier time keeping the passion alive.

**Conclusion**

For neurodivergent folks, people who enjoy their independence and autonomy, or individuals allergic to their partner's pets, LAT is a fine option for keeping and deepening romantic partnerships. It takes work like all relationships do. And yeah, unlike living together, you'll have to make more of an effort to communicate. But if you're happy with a partner, you don't have to live with them, especially if that doesn't sound like a great time. Instead, you can live apart together. I mean-if Helena Bonham Carter and Tim Burton could live apart for their 13-year marriage and still be happy, why can't you? title: Behold, Your Reason to Date a Golden Retriever Boyfriend

**Title**
Behold, Your Reason to Date a Golden Retriever Boyfriend

**Overview**
Heyl discusses the idealized relationship archetype known as the "Golden Retriever Boyfriend" based on TikTok videos and explores its potential benefits and red flags.

*   A Golden Retriever Boyfriend is outgoing, affectionate, and game for anything.
*   They're also clingy and codependent on your presence to be happy.
*   This relationship archetype emphasizes the importance of loyalty and a sunny disposition.

**Qualities of a Golden Retriever Boyfriend**

1.  A Golden Retriever Boyfriend is always ready to listen, has a deep sense of loyalty, and a smile that spreads across his face anytime he sees you.
2.  They're outgoing, easily excited, and are game for doing silly things.
3.  However, they can be overly clingy and codependent on your presence.

**Benefits of Having a Golden Retriever Boyfriend**

*   You'll have a warm, optimistic, loyal, kind, and appreciative partner.
*   This relationship archetype emphasizes the importance of loyalty and a sunny disposition.

**Things Aren't Always As They Seem**

1.  Idealization can be problematic when we focus solely on the positive attributes of someone or something, leading us to minimize any negative qualities.
2.  Nothing is all good nor all bad in relationships; insisting a relationship only has good qualities means overlooking reality.
3.  This sets us up for disappointment and is unfair to our partner.

**Red Flags to Watch Out for in a Golden Retriever Boyfriend**

1.  If your partner relies only on you for social connection, isolation can occur.
2.  Guilt tripping you for working, seeing family or friends without him, or focusing all energy on him are red flags.
3.  The relationship may be consistently focused on being silly and lighthearted, creating issues when there's conflict.

**How to Cultivate Golden Retriever Boyfriend Qualities**

1.  Practice active listening by hearing what your partner is saying rather than just responding.
2.  Look into each other's love languages and provide love in the preferred language.
3.  Consider reaching out to a therapist if you're stuck in comparison cycles.

**Conclusion**
The Golden Retriever Boyfriend archetype can be both beneficial and problematic, highlighting the importance of balance and realistic expectations in relationships. While cultivating its qualities through active listening and love languages can strengthen connections, being aware of potential red flags is essential for maintaining healthy relationships. By understanding the nuances of this idealized relationship archetype, individuals can navigate their own relationships more effectively. **Depression**

Depression is a serious mental health condition that affects millions of people worldwide.

*   It can cause persistent sadness, a depressed mood, and diminished interest in previously enjoyable activities.
*   Depression often arises from a complex combination of factors, including genetics, family history, trauma, stress, and illness.

**Living with Depression**

Living with depression can be challenging, but there are ways to cope with the condition.

1.  Getting enough sleep
2.  Eating a healthy diet
3.  Finding social support
4.  Engaging in regular physical activity

These self-help strategies can help improve well-being and alleviate symptoms of depression.

**Frequently Asked Questions**

*   How do you cope with depression?
*   What are some ways to support someone with depression?
*   Is depression genetic?
*   Is there a cure for depression?

**Key Terms**

*   Mood Disorder: A broad class of mental health conditions that primarily impact emotional states.
*   Psychiatric Evaluation: An assessment utilized by psychiatrists to diagnose mental health conditions.
*   Dysthymia: A chronic state of depression characterized by low mood, loss of interest, sleep changes, and appetite changes.
*   Psychosis: A mental state that involves losing contact with reality.
*   Seasonal Affective Disorder: A mood disorder that occurs the same time each year due to reduced sunlight.
*   Postpartum Depression: A serious but treatable form of depression that generally occurs after giving birth.

**Explore Depression**

Depression is a complex condition, and there are many resources available for those affected by it. Some topics include:

1.  Causes of treatment-resistant depression
2.  Symptoms of clinical depression
3.  Diagnosis according to the DSM-5
4.  Overview of treatments for depression

These resources can provide valuable information and support for individuals living with depression.

**Staying Informed**

*   Depression is a treatable condition.
*   Self-help strategies can help improve well-being and alleviate symptoms of depression.
*   Living with depression requires support from loved ones, healthcare professionals, and mental health organizations.  .

title: I've Been Single for 4 Years. Is My Smut-Reading Habit to Blame?

It's not a substitute for professional advice or treatment. If you have concerns about your relationship or sex life, please consult with a mental health professional.  *This post was medically reviewed by Ivy Kwong, LMFT.* Read the full disclaimer here. **When Reading Smut Bleeds into Real Life**

Perhaps, I've been single for too long (I have), but I often fantasize about book characters and wonder: why can't I have that in real life? These book boyfriends are *literally* killing their enemies to protect their women and meanwhile, I can't get a text back. And I'm not the only one who feels this way. So many BookTokers have made videos comparing the disappointment that is real-life men to fictional characters. And yes, I understand these characters are fictional but what they're doing-being intentional and communicative, showing love and care-is what I want from my partner. Are my expectations too high or am I being delusional and ignoring how IRL dating works?

**What Does Reading Smut Say About Relationships, Dating, and Sex?**

There's nothing wrong with reading erotica or smut. If anything, it's a form of escapism, says Dr. Hertlein. The growing popularity of romance and erotic novels suggests that more people are enjoying the escapism that comes with getting into these kinds of stories. More people are also eager to learn about their sexual desires, says Dr. Janet Brito, a sex therapist and founder of The Sexual Health School. She credits the popularization of smut to individuals seeking inspiration to improve their own sex lives and the rising interest in different relationship types like polyamory. Even single people like myself who avidly read smut can find value.

Research shows that consuming sexually explicit content helps people feel more sexually confident with themselves and their bodies.1 I wasn't taught to feel okay with sex and sexual desires, but erotica and smut have become safe spaces for me to explore arousal and excitement with less shame and guilt.

**How to Have a Healthy Sex Life While Reading Smut (Because, Yes, It's Possible)**

Sometimes, we readers get swept up in the fantasies. Eyes so glued to the paperback novel that IRL intimacy and sex have become non-existent. While a smut addiction does not exist, according to Dr. Brito, there is such a thing as too much smut, especially if it's beginning to impact your relationships.

It may become unhealthy if you're neglecting other responsibilities or avoiding engagement in real-life relationships, she says. In other words, if you're forgoing intimacy with your partner because they don't perform like the book boyfriends or are abandoning quality time with your S.O. because you're too focused on the novel, you might need to cut back on the smut.

You don't have to quit entirely but establishing boundaries could help. To maintain a healthy relationship with erotica without damaging your sexual and romantic relationships, set limits on reading time to ensure it doesn't interfere with quality time with your partner, Dr. Hertlein says. Prioritize real-life intimacy by consciously focusing on physical and emotional connections with your partner over fictional experiences.

Always reflect on your desire to read erotica, Dr. Hertlein adds. If you're reading smut because you like it, great! But if you find yourself obsessed with the sex or romance in the novel because it's lacking in your own life and preventing you from real-life intimacy, maybe it's time to put the smut reading on pause for reflection and in-person connection.

**So, Does Smut Ruin Dating?**

The short answer? No. The long answer? Too much smut may create intimacy, dating, and relationship issues. But that's where discernment comes in. Accept that romance and smut books are primarily designed for entertainment, Dr. Brito advises. They often feature characters with ideal qualities and nearly perfect relationships.

While they may include elements of real-life scenarios, their main purpose is to entertain you. Certain things like weird and awkward sex or miscommunication just aren't entertaining, so most romance and erotica won't include them. But that doesn't mean they don't happen in real life.

Not every sexual moment between you and your partner (or even yourself) will be as magical as the novels claim. And dating sometimes sucks! Your perfect partner may not be a billionaire mafioso who kills any man who looks at you. It's very unlikely you'll randomly stumble upon the heir to a multi-million-dollar corporation and fake marry him to save your family from their rising debt.

Frankly, you'll likely kiss lots of toads before you meet a prince. Because, unfortunately, that's the real world. And we live there, not in the sentences and fragments of an author.

**Takeaways**

It's so easy to get swept into the romanticism of it all, but becoming disconnected from reality and lost in fantasy only leads to disappointment and maybe sadness, resentment, and despair. Dating is already hard and I don't need to make it any harder by being delusional. Finding a book boyfriend (does a thing even exist?) is not as easy as these female protagonists proclaim.

And even if I find one, there's no certainty that we'll be compatible, have a happily ever after, or even have a good sex life. Hell, we may break up after two to three years. The story may be set in stone but reality isn't. Keep that in mind the next time you're scrolling on Hinge and believe you found the *one.* Chances are, they're nothing more than another number. **History**
Romantic relationships between people with many years between them date back to evolutionary times. Schools of thought once believed age-gap relationships were a product of human nature, where men sought women in their peak reproductive years to have children.1 Now, there are obvious flaws in this thought process—the greatest being this belief is heteronormative.

**Psychological and Social Dynamics**
There is something to be said about preferring an older partner. A study found a link between age and confidence, suggesting self-assurance is why younger partners seek out older partners. This same study also reported older partners are more accepting of younger counterparts.1 It goes without saying that many couples with an age gap find each other specifically because of their shared life goals and trajectories, despite their age difference, which is why they work, says clinical psychologist and holistic therapist Kim Slipski, MA, LMFT.

**Do Age Gap Relationships Work?**

*   Anna's Story: In my experience, what works well in an age gap relationship is the balance between our different energies and approaches to life. A big part of their component is learning from each other, which she finds fulfilling.
*   Carter's Story: We just happened to fall in love with each other, like any other relationship.

**Challenges**
A study on Korean couples found an age gap of over three years resulted in an elevated risk for depressive symptoms, with the odds increasing with every one-to-two years of age difference.2 This isn't to say age gap relationships are doomed, but they do come with their own unique set of challenges.

**Stigmas**
If you're facing judgment for your relationship, it is important to begin with some honesty and self-reflection. Is there a problematic age difference due to the different life stages you two are in? Do lingering issues of a power imbalance loom? Are you two simply not aligned on your long-term wants and needs?

**How to Maintain a Healthy Relationship**

*   In any relationship, it's important to keep learning about each other's personalities, bodies, and worlds.
*   Stepping into each other's shoes can help you understand differing perspectives and life experiences. (Psychologists called this building love maps, says Slipski).
*   Consider couples therapy if things are getting bumpy but both parties are committed to seeing the relationship through.
*   Allow yourself to be fully present.

**Help! My Roommate Is Ruining My Life**

A bad roommate can make home sweet home anything but. Here's how to deal.

By Noma Nazish, Published on July 29, 2024
Verywell Mind

Getty Images

**Table of Contents**
===============

*   [Understanding the Situation](#understanding-the-situation)
*   [Weighing Your Options](#weighing-your-options)
*   [Communication Strategies](#communication-strategies)
*   [Conflict Resolution](#conflict-resolution)
*   [Seeking Mediation or External Help](#seeking-mediation-or-external-help)
*   [Self-Care and Coping Strategies](#self-care-and-coping-strategies)
*   [Knowing When to Seek Alternative Living Arrangements](#knowing-when-to-seek-alternative-living-arrangements)

**Understanding the Situation**
=============================

Dealing with a bad roommate can be stressful. But with the right communication and conflict resolution techniques, it's possible to work things out and establish a harmonious relationship.

### Types of Bad Roommates

*   The Noisemaker: Your roommate is always too loud or throws late-night parties without notice.
*   The Slob: They never clean up after themselves and treat the whole place like their personal dumpster.
*   The Borrower: They take your things without asking and don't return them.
*   The Passive-Aggressive: They show bitterness and hostility when they feel hurt or offended but never tell you what's bothering them.
*   The Drama King or Queen: They are constantly surrounded by drama, seeking validation or sympathy.

**Weighing Your Options**
=====================

So, how can you address the issues you're having with your roommate in a constructive way? It could include strategies like improving communication, practicing assertiveness, and setting boundaries.

### Strategies to Deal With Dysregulation

*   Improve Communication: Have open conversations and practice assertiveness instead of passive aggression.
*   Set Boundaries: Create ground rules after mutual discussion.
*   Self-Care: Prioritize self-care to manage stress and improve emotional regulation.

**Communication Strategies**
==========================

Communication is not the same as confrontation. Keep in mind that communication should be an attempt to share feelings openly without worrying about being attacked for what you are feeling or needing.

### Six Key Communication Strategies

*   Use I Statements: Frame your concerns using 'I' statements to avoid sounding accusatory.
*   Practice Non-Violent Communication (NVC): Remove blame and use empathy and neutral language.
*   Keep Your Body Language Non-Aggressive: Make sure your body language is open and non-threatening while maintaining eye contact.
*   Explain Rather Than Complain: Clearly define what the problem is and how it affects you and the shared living space.
*   Assume Positive Intent: Sometimes, when other people don't behave favorably, they might simply be unaware or doing their best but still making mistakes.

**Conflict Resolution**
=====================

When you live with others, conflicts are bound to happen over one thing or another. However, with a well-defined approach to conflict resolution, you don't have to avoid or overreact to these situations.

### Step-by-Step Strategy for Conflict Resolution

1.  Evaluate the Problem: Identify the issue and consider how it impacts you so you can communicate it to your roommate.
2.  See If It's Actually a Dispute: Determine if the issue is worth discussing.
3.  Pick the Right Time: Set a time and place to discuss the issue when both of you are calm and better able to communicate.
4.  Listen Actively: Give your roommate a chance to share their perspective and listen to them without interrupting.
5.  Seek Common Ground: Identify common objectives and work towards a solution.

**Seeking Mediation or External Help**
=====================================

Involving a neutral third party, such as a counselor or a resident advisor, can help roommates resolve their differences by providing an unbiased perspective and a structured framework for facilitating a constructive dialogue.

### Benefits of Seeking Mediation

*   A third-party mediator would be able to ensure the conversation stays on track and doesn't spiral into personal attacks.
*   They are less likely to have tunnel vision when trying to resolve the situation and can come up with out-of-the-box solutions.

**Self-Care and Coping Strategies**
====================================

When there is conflict at home, you experience physiological and psychological symptoms of fight-or-flight and anticipatory anxiety. It's essential to prioritize self-care to manage stress and improve emotional regulation.

### Five Expert-Backed Self-Care Strategies

*   Practice Mindfulness: Practicing mindfulness and relaxation techniques like breathwork, yoga, or gratitude journaling can significantly reduce stress and anxiety.
*   Create a Personal Retreat: Establish a personal space where you can retreat to break away from daily stressors and unwind.
*   Get Moving: Regular physical activity helps lower cortisol levels and releases endorphins, which are natural stress relievers.
*   Don't Take It Personally: Know that whatever is happening is not personal. You could have 10 roommates and say the same thing to each one of them, and they will all react differently.
*   Put Your Creative Hat On: Engaging in creative hobbies like painting, writing, or knitting can help take your mind off roommate troubles.

**Knowing When to Seek Alternative Living Arrangements**
=====================================================

Sometimes our fundamental needs and values conflict with those of our roommates. In this case, there may be no way around it but to transition to a new living situation.

### Signs It's Time to Move On

*   You have more L's (leave) than S's (stay) in your notepad.
*   Your roommate is consistently causing stress and anxiety.
*   You've tried addressing the issues, but they persist.

**Race and Social Justice**

### LIVING WELL Race and Social Justice
Race is everywhere. It plays an important role in our identity and shapes our perspectives including how we think and feel about mental health.

There are many mental health considerations unique to certain racial and cultural groups. The stigmatization of bisexual men, the strong Black women stereotype, and the lack of mental health services for Indigenous communities. These are just a few examples of how race and culture align with mental health and wellness.

Learn more about the relationship between your identity, your racial group, and your mental health here.

### What's the Difference Between Race and Ethnicity?

The Intersection of LGBTQIA+ and BIPOC Identities

### FREQUENTLY ASKED QUESTIONS
What is the concept of race?
The dictionary by Merriam-Webster defines race as a category of humankind that shares certain distinctive physical traits.

1. Race is usually associated with biology and linked with physical characteristics, such as hair texture or skin color, and covers a relatively narrow range of options.
Yet people of similar complexions hair textures can be defined as different races, and definitions in the United States have changed over time.

### What are the six categories of race?
When completing paperwork that asks for race, you may be asked to identify yourself as belonging to one or more of the following categories:

*   White
*   Black or African American
*   Asian American
*   American Indian or Alaska Native
*   Native Hawaiian or Pacific Islander
*   Some other race

While some may be considered to be of a certain race, Black people, for example, may identify more with their individual ethnicity, as opposed to race. This could apply to any member of any race.

### Learn More:
Race vs. Ethnicity

Why is it important to learn about race and ethnicity?
Conversations about race and ethnicity are key to building empathy, facilitating acceptance, understanding, and respect for those with people from other backgrounds.

Such histories of other cultures and races are often erased or minimized from mainstream narratives, so it is essential to learn about the struggles and experiences of marginalized groups.

### Learn More:
Why It's Important to Learn About Indigenous Peoples

### KEY TERMS
BIPOC Inclusion Diversity Microaggressions Cultural Assimilation Intersectionality

*   **BIPOC**: The acronym BIPOC stands for Black, Indigenous, and People Of Color and is pronounced buy-pock as opposed to saying each letter individually. The BIPOC acronym builds on the former acronym of POC (people of color), acknowledging that not all people of color have the same experiences or deal with the same types of injustice.
*   **Inclusion**: Inclusion refers to the act or practice of including and accommodating people who have historically been excluded (because of their race, gender, sexuality, or ability).
*   **Diversity**: Diversity refers to the quality of representing people from a range of different social and ethnic backgrounds and of different genders, sexual orientations, etc.
*   **Microaggressions**: A microaggression is a subtle verbal or nonverbal behavior, committed consciously or not, that is directed at a member of a marginalized group, and has a harmful, derogatory effect.
*   **Cultural Assimilation**: Cultural assimilation refers to the act of sacrificing one's own culture to adopt the lifestyle, behaviors, and beliefs of the dominant culture group.
*   **Intersectionality**: The term intersectionality was first coined by civil rights scholar Kimberlé Crenshaw in the late '80s. It refers to an individual's multiple identities and how they're subject to various forms of intersecting oppression.

title: Stress Management
content:
Health Care

**Overview**

Stress Management is essential for maintaining overall health and well-being. We must be aware of how we respond to stress in our lives, as it can significantly impact happiness and satisfaction levels. With the right plan and mindfulness, anyone can develop strong stress management skills.

**Effects on Health**

Chronic stress can lead to various health issues, including:

1. Increased cortisol levels
2. Weight gain or loss
3. Insomnia
4. Digestive problems
5. Weakened immune system

**Management Techniques**

To effectively manage stress, consider the following techniques:

*   Practice mindfulness and meditation
*   Engage in regular exercise
*   Prioritize sleep and maintain a healthy routine
*   Use positive self-talk and reframing negative thoughts
*   Set realistic goals and boundaries
*   Seek support from loved ones or professionals

**Real-Life Applications**

Many people have found success with various stress management techniques, including:

1.  Digital detox before bed
2.  Reframing perspectives on atopic dermatitis
3.  Practicing self-preservation for mental health
4.  Using the "spoon theory" to manage chronic illness
5.  Implementing mindfulness and chair yoga in daily routines

**Conclusion**

Stress management is a crucial aspect of overall well-being, and it's never too late to develop effective coping strategies. By understanding the effects of stress on our health and incorporating practical techniques into our lives, we can lead more fulfilling and balanced lives.

title: Is Depression Hereditary?
content:
Last Updated: August 24, 2023 Aron Janssen, MD Dr. Aron Janssen is a board-certified psychiatrist and Assistant Professor in the Departments of Psychiatry and Family Medicine at the University of Central Florida College of Medicine. He has published articles on various topics including mental health stigma, sleep disorders, addiction, and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Last Updated: August 24, 2023

**Is Depression Hereditary?**

Depression is a complex condition that can be caused by a combination of genetic, environmental, and psychological factors. While there may be a heritable component to depression, genetics is not the only determinant. Other factors contribute to risk, while some can be protective.

*   A child who has a parent with depression may have a genetic predisposition but will not necessarily become depressed.
*   On the other hand, a child who does not have a family member with depression and is not genetically predisposed to the condition may become depressed if they are exposed to a triggering event such as experiencing a trauma.

**The Role of Genetics in Depression**

Research has demonstrated that genes play a role in the potential risk for many health conditions, including depression. Studies have suggested there is a heritable component to depression. Some research has also indicated that women may be more susceptible to the genetic influences associated with depression than men.

*   When studying depression or other health conditions, researchers often look for changes in genes called variants.
*   These changes are classified according to the effect (if any) they have on the gene.
*   Families can often predict what color a child's eyes will be by looking to parents and other close relatives, but variants can behave unexpectedly.

**Understanding Genetic Variations**

Heredity is a complex interplay of many factors, not just individual genes. When studying depression or other health conditions, researchers often look for changes in genes called variants. These changes are classified according to the effect (if any) they have on the gene.

*   Having a genetic variant can make it more likely-but not definitive-that you will develop a condition associated with that variant.
*   If a gene associated with a specific condition is altered, it may be more (or less) likely to contribute to the development of that condition.

**Can Genetics Affect Mental Health Treatment?**

Depression can be treated with medication, psychotherapy, and other interventions like cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT). Some people may be prescribed a combination of treatments. Your genes may influence how well a specific treatment works for you.

*   Research has indicated that certain genes might affect how well your body absorbs, uses, and excretes alcohol and drugs, including antidepressant medications.
*   Several genes are known to influence drug metabolism, but the results from these studies are primarily of interest to doctors and researchers.

**Does Heritability of Depression Affect Children?**

People with depression might be concerned they will pass on the condition to their children. While there could be a heritable component to depression, genetics is not the only determinant. Other factors contribute to risk, while some can be protective. A child who has a parent with depression may have a genetic predisposition but will not necessarily become depressed.

*   On the other hand, a child who does not have a family member with depression and is not genetically predisposed to the condition may become depressed if they are exposed to a triggering event such as experiencing a trauma. Other known factors that contribute to all forms of depression and other mental health conditions include: brain chemistry changes in brain structure hormone imbalances extreme stress

**Summary**

Having a genetic predisposition to depression can exacerbate these factors and may influence when someone becomes depressed as well as how long symptoms may last. However, it's essential to remember that depression can develop in anyone-even someone who isn't genetically predisposed and isn't susceptible to known risk factors.

*   Identifying the signs of depression and being able to recognize them in yourself and others is crucial to ensuring the condition doesn't go untreated.
*   If you or a loved one are struggling with depression, contact the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA) National Helpline at 1-800-662-4357 for information on support and treatment facilities in your area. For more mental health resources, see our National Helpline Database.

**Sources**

¹ "Is Depression Hereditary?" by Nancy Schimelpfening

² Research studies have suggested that someone with a first-degree relative diagnosed with depression (a parent, sibling, or child) could be three times more likely to be diagnosed with depression in their lifetime compared to the general population. 3 "Depression and Genetics" by the National Institute of Mental Health.

³ Some research has also indicated that women may be more susceptible to the genetic influences associated with depression than men. 5 Why Some People Are More Prone to Depression

6 These changes are classified according to the effect (if any) they have on the gene.

7 Research has identified several genetic variants associated with depression, but no single gene has been definitively linked to the condition.

8 Can Genetics Affect Mental Health Treatment?

9 While some consumer genomic test kits provide information about topics like drug metabolism, genomic testing is not the same as genetic testing. 

10 Additional research is needed to understand what findings from genetic studies could mean for antidepressants as well as other medications used to treat depression.

11  Talk to your doctor before using your genomic health information to make decisions about your healthcare, including your depression treatment.

12 Does Heritability of Depression Affect Children? People with depression might be concerned they will pass on the condition to their children. While there could be a heritable component to depression, genetics is not the only determinant. Other factors contribute to risk, while some can be protective.

13 Non-Genetic Causes of Depression Genetics is one of several potential causes of depression. Knowing the possible causes can help you better understand depression, but remember that depression can also develop in the absence of a clear cause and be difficult to pinpoint.

However, it's essential to remember that depression can develop in anyone-even someone who isn't genetically predisposed and isn't susceptible to known risk factors.

title: I Tried Meditation for My Depression-Here's What I Learned
content:
& Report Content Issues   **I Tried Meditation for My Depression-Here's What I Learned**

**Find what works for you**

By John Loeppky

Published on January 09, 2025

Verywell Mind Stocksy

**Table of Contents**

*   How Meditation Can Help With Depression
*   How to Get Started
*   What Types of Meditation Work Best
*   Tips for Meditation Success
*   Disclaimer

**How Meditation Can Help With Depression**

Meditation can help some people mitigate their depression symptoms. According to experts, using meditation as a form of treatment should be in collaboration with your care team and should not be considered a one-stop-shop solution to mental health conditions.

I don't know about you but I initially found meditation incredibly difficult to understand. I have a physical disability and multiple mental health conditions, including depression and an anxiety disorder. Even my physical disability, cerebral palsy, is inherently tied to my brain. Some days, to call me a mess is an understatement, but at least my brain damage is visible on a scan.

In my mid-20s through five-ish years ago-meditation as a treatment option seemed not just sensible, but inevitable. If everyone else was doing it-even on the Canadian prairies where I live-why wasn't I? However, when I was first asked to try mindfulness meditation, I was at a loss.

What do you mean you want me to sit here, and imagine the traffic floating by, and contemplate my thoughts without getting into those imaginary cars? What if I wanted to get into one of those cars? What if they were going somewhere cool? What if the vehicle was self-driving? What if they were going to San Francisco? I'd love to go to San Francisco.

Sometimes, my mind would float away to my to-do list, or my day job at the time working at an arts non-profit, or the weather, or anything but the calmness I was supposed to focus on. I eventually did find a mindfulness practice that worked for me, yoga nidra, but that was after many months of trial and error.

Here's hoping this article can help you find a meditation practice for your mental health a little smoother and easier.

**How Meditation Can Help With Depression**

The causes of depression are complicated and not fully understood, Some point to genetics, others to physiology, and factors such as stress and anxiety. Brent Nelson, MD, adult interventional psychiatrist and chief medical information officer at PrairieCare, says that for him, the focus on the brain is a helpful framework to understand how meditation can help with depression.

The brain has 100 billion neurons with 100 trillion connections, so it's very complicated, Nelson says. And the cause of depression is still yet to be fully understood, but we know it's a complex process. It's often interleaved with other things such as anxiety or trauma, and really, for a lot of people, is a function of stress meeting, maybe, an underlying genetic predisposition.

Meditation, when used to treat depression, is not isolated on an island. When suggested by a psychologist, a psychiatrist, or a therapist, meditation is often used alongside medications, methodologies like cognitive-behavioral therapy, and treatments like transcranial magnetic stimulation.

Nelson tells Verywell Mind that he often starts patients with mindfulness meditations. A lot of times we will start with mindfulness meditation because what it really can let people do is get their brain to be more connected, kind of in the moment, in the here and now, and less so in the distant past or anxiety over the future, which often can be a challenge in depression, he adds.

**What [mindfulness meditation] really can let people do is get their brain to be more connected, kind of in the moment, in the here and now, and less so in the distant past or anxiety over the future, which often can be a challenge in depression.**

- BRENT NELSON, MD

Julie Potiker, a certified mindful self-compassion teacher of the UCSD's Center for Mindfulness believes that meditation is a key reason why she was able to recover from her bouts with depression.

It's not at all like loosey-goosey or woo woo, or anything like that... I used to be a clinically depressed person, and I used to take antidepressants, and I had postpartum depression, so I'm really a poster child for this...Mindful self-compassion, that's what I leaned into, and that's why I became a teacher of it, and then that's why I became certified in it, she says.

**How to Fight Depression Without Medication**

**How to Get Started**

Potiker, who tends to focus initially on a loving-kindness meditation, says that zeroing in on self-compassion and gratitude can be especially valuable for those facing depression, in her experience. In terms of getting started, her recent advice to someone she supports-rather than building up meditation to be a big burdensome practice-was to start small.

I talked to her about little micro-moments, trying to do it once an hour, Potiker explains. Where you either look out the window or you take a walk, or you play one of your favorite songs, or something that makes your body feel good, and you enrich it and absorb it for moments, I don't mean minutes, and you just really feel because it just folds right into gratitude.

**8-Minute Video Meditation to Becoming More Mindful**

**What Types of Meditation Work Best**

A 2015 analysis looked at seven different meditation techniques and their effectiveness. Those included:

1.  Mindfulness-based cognitive therapy
2.  Patañjali Yoga
3.  Qigong
4.  Sahaj Yoga
5.  Inner Resources Meditation
6.  Sudarshan Kriya Yoga
7.  Tai Chi

Nelson says that, when in doubt, patients should refer back to the medical professionals supporting them. He says this can include asking your care team about local resources, including regional centers tied to local universities that are studying and implementing meditation strategies for those with mental health disorders.

It's always going back to your treatment team, and having a multi-specialty treatment team that can really look at this particular unique individual from a few different perspectives and help give good, reliable guidance, Nelson adds.

**How You Should Meditate, According to Your Personality**

**Tips for Meditation Success**

Meditation can help mitigate depression symptoms when used in conjunction with a professional treatment plan. Here are some tips to get the most out of your practice:

*   Speak to a professional: Meditation is only a smaller part of a broader care plan including medication, therapy, and lifestyle changes.
*   Make sure you are working with an accredited and recommended practitioner.
*   Focus on something you can sustain: You don't need to have a perfect meditation practice and it may take time to find the right type of meditation that works for you.
*   Make sure you're in a safe space: If you're triggered by the type of meditation you are doing, and if you feel unsafe, find a way to self-regulate. This might look like leaving the session, getting a drink of water, or trying an entirely different type of meditation.

Psychology is the study of the human mind. It plays a significant role in our behaviors, emotions, relationships, personality, and much more.

title: How to Cope With Depression and Anxiety at the Same Time
content:
on This Article 1. Elena Touroni PhD. Consultant Psychologist & Co-Founder of The Chelsea Psychology Clinic, London. Interviewed by Adam England on September 25, 2024. 2. Gin Lalli BSc HPD DSFH Solutions-Focused Therapist and Coach. Interviewed by Adam England on September 23, 2024. 3. Sham Singh MD Psychiatrist at WINIT Clinic. Interviewed by Adam England on September 28, 2024.

**Coping When You Have Both**

It's common for depression and anxiety to co-exist, and having both can be more difficult for us to cope with than having just one or the other-though it's different for everyone.

Medication, therapy, and lifestyle changes can all help us cope.

### Medication

*   Medication can be useful, but it can differ from person to person.
*   I never got on with medication really-Zoloft (sertraline) made my depression ten times worse, it felt like, Elisha explains.
*   Lee, 25, meanwhile, has tried various medications, and has been on Effexor (venlafaxine) for just over a year.
*   They've upped the dosage a few times now and I now take it three times a day, she says.
*   They haven't managed to find something that works for my anxiety yet, but I've found if I can manage the depression then that has a knock-on effect and I don't struggle so much with the anxiety.

### Therapy

*   Dr Touroni advises seeking professional support to address both depression and anxiety holistically.
*   She advises developing your own 'toolkit' of coping mechanisms, which might comprise a mix of therapy, lifestyle changes, and perhaps medication.
*   Many of her clients have found cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) useful because:
    *   It addresses both anxiety and depression by helping to challenge negative thought patterns and manage overwhelming emotions.
*   Sham Singh, MD, a psychiatrist at WINIT Clinic, says, In dealing with anxiety and depression, I look at their underlying causes, which might be emotional or environmental, but at times even biological.
*   This comprehensive approach will help not only in relieving symptoms but also in preventing their recurrence.

### Lifestyle Changes

*   Making lifestyle changes can also help-for Lee, keeping routines is helpful for anxiety.
*   There's less chance of getting anxious if I know what's going to happen; but on the flip side, it makes it worse if something unexpected happens, she explains.
*   You may decide to try mindfulness and grounding techniques yourself, too, whether they're things you've explored in therapy or not.
*   Dr. Touroni describes them as being incredibly helpful in managing anxiety, letting us focus on the present rather than spiraling into worrying about the future.
*   She also recommends setting small, achievable goals for depression-take one step at a time, celebrate any wins no matter how small, and recognize the progress you're making.

### Physical Activity

*   Physical activity can help reduce anxiety and boost your mood, so even going for a short walk, if you feel up to it, can help.
*   While Morgan is on medication for her anxiety and depression, she does this too.
*   I thrive on keeping routines, making set times to do things I love, and giving myself plenty of grace.
*   I tackle one thing my depression wants me to avoid every day, like cleaning my room, to stop myself from getting too anxious.

### Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy for Depression and Anxiety

1.  Address both anxiety and depression by helping to challenge negative thought patterns and manage overwhelming emotions.
2.  Focus on the present rather than spiraling into worrying about the future.
3.  Set small, achievable goals for depression-take one step at a time, celebrate any wins no matter how small, and recognize the progress you're making.

### How To Talk To People About It (If You Want To)

Talking to people about our depression and anxiety isn't always easy-often, people might just not be able to relate, even if they mean well.

*   If you do decide to talk to people in your life, like friends, about depression and anxiety, it's fine to bring it up in conversation, or ask them if you'd be able to have a conversation with them.
*   Of course, it's easier said than done, and I've often struggled to reach out-particularly because I internalized ideas that men are meant to be 'strong' and not discuss their feelings
*   Reaching out and talking to people is often the first step.
*   We can often be pleasantly surprised with how our loved ones react.
*   And if you don't feel able to talk to people in your life, you may find support online from people going through the same thing as us.

### What to Do When You Need Someone to Talk To

Most importantly, seeking support-whether through therapy, support groups, or talking to loved ones-is key to not feeling isolated in this struggle, says Dr. Touroni.

*   Dr Singh says that he encourages his clients to be patient with themselves - and again, that any progress is great.
*   That, combined with therapy and proper self-care routines such as regular exercise and sleep, can go a long way toward recovery, he says.

While living with depression and anxiety concurrently can be a real struggle, there are ways to cope, whether that's opening up to loved ones, making lifestyle changes if we're able to, or trying therapy or medication. It's different for everybody, so it's a good idea for us to try out different coping mechanisms and strategies to find something that works.

**Conclusion**

Living with depression and anxiety can be a challenging experience, but it's not impossible to cope with. By understanding the relationship between these two conditions, seeking support, and trying different coping mechanisms, individuals can find ways to manage their symptoms and improve their quality of life.

It's essential to remember that everyone's journey is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. Be patient with yourself, and don't be afraid to seek help when you need it. With the right support and strategies, you can learn to live with depression and anxiety and find a sense of hope and healing.

**CONDITIONS A-Z**

**Eating Disorders**
 Living With Bulimia
 Anorexia Symptoms and Diagnosis
 Treatment
 Medically reviewed by Rachel Goldman, PhD, FTOS
 Updated on July 19, 2024

An eating disorder is a mental health condition in which the person affected experiences significant disruptions in their eating behaviors as well as in their thoughts and emotions related to food. People who struggle with eating disorders often become preoccupied with food and their body weight.

These conditions can be life-threatening if left untreated. Additionally, eating disorders often occur together with other mental health issues like depression, anxiety, panic disorders, and obsessive-compulsive disorders.

Without treatment, eating disorders can cause a number of health-related problems including cardiovascular issues, gastrointestinal issues, and malnutrition. However, with proper treatment, people affected by eating disorders can resume healthy eating habits and can improve their mental health.

**IMPACT OF EATING DISORDERS**

*   What to Do If Your Teen Shows Signs of Bulimia
*   Why Do Some People Get Eating Disorders?
*   How Is Anorexia Nervosa Diagnosed?
*   What to Know About Anorexia in Men

**FREQUENTLY ASKED QUESTIONS**

Could you have an eating disorder? Determining if you have an eating disorder begins with examining your thoughts and behaviors surrounding food, body image, and body weight.

Although there is an extensive list of warning signs, not everyone will display every symptom. If you suspect you have an eating disorder, it's essential to talk to your doctor or a mental health professional.

The chance for recovery increases the sooner an eating disorder is addressed. Learn More: Symptoms of Eating Disorders

What causes eating disorders? Eating disorders are complex disorders that stem from a variety of factors including genetics, cultural ideals, environmental, psychological, and biological influences.

These risk factors may also include mental health conditions like anxiety and depression along with body image issues. Learn More: Causes of Eating Disorders

How can you help someone with an eating disorder? To help a loved one with an eating disorder, be supportive of their recovery efforts without trying to fix, control, or counsel them.

Instead, be patient and encouraging. Empower them to tackle their disordered eating and talk to a counselor or therapist. Are eating disorders genetic? There is some evidence that eating disorders are heritable.

In fact, in one study of twins, researchers discovered that 40% to 60% of the risk for anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, and binge eating disorder arises from genetic influences. However, the development of an eating disorder is a complex process impacted by various factors and not just about genetic influences.

Learn More: What Causes an Eating Disorder?

**KEY TERMS**

*   Anorexia Nervosa
*   Bulimia Nervosa
*   Binge-Eating Disorder
*   Rumination Disorder
*   Avoidant Restrictive Food Intake Disorder
*   Psychological Evaluation
*   Family-Based Therapy
*   Cognitive Behavioral Therapy

**ANOREXIA NERVOSA**

Anorexia nervosa is an eating disorder characterized by not eating enough and impacts all areas of a person's life. A person affected by anorexia nervosa may have a low body weight and a distorted body image.

They also may have an intense fear of gaining weight and often use extreme measures to control their weight and shape. Warning Signs of Anorexia Nervosa

**BULIMIA NERVOSA**

Bulimia nervosa is an eating disorder characterized by binge eating followed by purging or another method designed to prevent weight gain such as the use of laxatives, excessive exercises, and fasting.

Due to guilt and shame associated with bulimia nervosa, people affected by this disorder will go to great lengths to hide their behaviors. Signs and Symptoms of Bulimia Nervosa

**BINGE-EATING DISORDER**

Binge eating is an eating disorder characterized by consuming large amounts of food even when the person isn't hungry.

Typically, the person feels out of control as well as a sense of shame and guilt over their binge eating. Unlike people with bulimia nervosa, they do not try to purge the food after it is consumed. What Is Binge Eating?

**RUMINATION DISORDER**

Rumination disorder is an eating disorder that involves bringing previously chewed or previously swallowed food back up in order to spit it out or re-swallow it.

These behaviors are often done in secret because of a fear of what people will think. What Is Rumination Disorder?

**AVOIDANT RESTRICTIVE FOOD INTAKE DISORDER**

ARFID is an eating disorder in which the person affected has a strong preference for a narrow range of foods and may refuse to eat any food that is outside of these parameters.

Unlike other eating disorders, people with ARFID do not worry about weight gain or body composition. Understanding Avoidant Restrictive Food Intake Disorder

**PSYCHOLOGICAL EVALUATION**

During a psychological evaluation, a psychologist or therapist will use a variety of tests and assessments to measure and observe a person's thoughts and behaviors.

At the completion of a psychological evaluation, the psychologist will make a diagnosis and recommend treatment options. How Eating Disorders Are Diagnosed

**FAMILY-BASED THERAPY**

Sometimes referred to as the Maudsley Method, family-based therapy (FBT) is the leading treatment option for treating adolescents with eating disorders.

FBT involves the whole family and primarily takes place in outpatient settings. It is the fastest and most effective treatment for children, adolescents, and young adults.

Family-Based Therapy for Eating Disorders

**COGNITIVE BEHAVIORAL THERAPY**

CBT is a type of treatment that focuses on helping a person learn how to identify destructive behaviors and thought processes.

Through CBT, a person's thoughts and behaviors are challenged and replaced with more realistic thoughts and behaviors. What Is Cognitive Behavioral Therapy?

title: An Overview of Persistent Depressive Disorder (Dysthymia)
content:
About This Article

**Title**
An Overview of Persistent Depressive Disorder (Dysthymia)

**Overview**
Persistent depressive disorder (PDD), formerly known as dysthymia, is a mood disorder characterized by a milder but more chronic form of depression. It reflects a spectrum of severity that can range from mild to severe.

*   This diagnosis represents a prolonged state of depression with fewer symptoms than major depressive disorder (MDD).
*   The symptoms are long-lasting and may be attributed to being stuck in a rut rather than as symptoms of a treatable condition.

**Symptoms of Persistent Depressive Disorder**
The symptoms of PDD are very similar to MDD, but there is a wider range of symptoms available on the criteria list for MDD. To receive a diagnosis of PDD, you must have at least three of the following seven symptoms:
*   A sad or depressed mood nearly every day.
*   Changes in appetite (poor appetite or overeating).
*   Sleep difficulties (too little or too much sleep).
*   Lack of energy or fatigue.
*   Poor self-esteem.
*   Hopelessness or feeling stuck in a rut.
*   Trouble concentrating or difficulty making decisions.

**Timeframe of Persistent Depressive Disorder**
The symptoms of PDD are chronic, meaning that people experience a depressed mood for most days for a period of at least two years. The timeframe has been reduced to one year for children and teens.

**Age of Onset**
PDD may have an earlier onset than MDD, with symptoms first appearing during the childhood, teen, or young adult years.

**Causes of Persistent Depressive Disorder**
Like other forms of depression, the exact cause of PDD is not known. However, a number of factors are believed to play a role, including:

*   Temperament
*   Environmental factors (e.g., parental loss or separation, childhood adversity, prolonged stress, grief, major life changes, and trauma)
*   Genetics
*   Brain chemistry

**Confirming a Diagnosis of PDD**
There is no laboratory test for diagnosing dysthymia or any other form of depression. If you are experiencing symptoms of depression, your doctor will evaluate your symptoms and medical history.

**Treatment for Persistent Depressive Disorder**
The treatments for PDD are similar to those for other forms of depression. Generally, a combination of psychotherapy and medications is the most effective.

*   Talk therapy: Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and interpersonal therapy (IPT)
*   Medications: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs)

**Coping With Persistent Depressive Disorder**
There are a number of different things that people can do to help cope with persistent depression. Some things that you can do include:

*   Avoiding alcohol and other substances
*   Creating daily routines that help structure and balance your day
*   Eating a healthy diet
*   Establishing a consistent sleep schedule
*   Getting regular exercise several times each week
*   Leaving the house and making plans with friends
*   Practicing stress management techniques such as journaling, taking a walk, and deep breathing

**Conclusion**
Even very mild symptoms of depression can disrupt your ability to function and enjoy life, particularly when these symptoms are long-lasting. Fortunately, there are effective treatments available for persistent depressive disorder that can make a major difference in your health and well-being. **Understanding Schizophrenia**

Schizophrenia is a mental illness that affects how the brain works, leading to chronic problems with disordered thoughts and behaviors.

*   Symptoms of schizophrenia include hallucinations, delusions, and lack of emotional expression.
*   It affects approximately 0.3% to 0.7% of people worldwide.
*   The exact causes are unknown but have both genetic and environmental risk factors.

**Causes and Risk Factors**

1.   Genetics: Research suggests that genetics play a significant role in causing schizophrenia, with having a family member with the condition increasing your risk of developing it.
2.   Environmental factors: A complex variety of influences likely contribute to the development of schizophrenia.
3.   Social factors: These can include social and cultural pressures.

**Treatment Options**

1.   Medications: Antipsychotics are commonly used to manage psychosis, but there is no cure for schizophrenia.
2.   Psychotherapy: Psychosocial interventions such as cognitive therapy and family intervention can be helpful in managing symptoms and improving functioning.
3.   Social support: Joining a peer support group or participating in social skills training can help individuals cope with the condition.

**Living with Schizophrenia**

1.   Early onset: Symptoms of schizophrenia typically begin to appear between late adolescence and early twenties, although they may start later or earlier.
2.   Age of onset: The age of onset is often later in women than in men.
3.   Gradual progression: Symptoms appear gradually and become progressively more severe.

**Key Terms**

*   Psychosis: A condition that affects the way the brain processes information and causes people to lose touch with reality.
*   Antipsychotics: Medications used primarily to manage psychosis.
*   Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT): A psychiatric treatment that involves using electrical stimulation to induce seizures, often used for treatment-resistant depression but sometimes used for schizophrenia that has not responded to treatment with antipsychotics.

title: Understanding Emotions
content:
Personal Growth Emotional Intelligence  Emotions are a vital part of the human experience, influencing our thoughts, behaviors, and relationships. Understanding emotions can help us navigate life's complexities, develop emotional intelligence, and cultivate healthy coping skills.

**The Importance of Emotions**

Emotions play a significant role in shaping who we are and how we interact with the world around us. They allow us to form connections, make decisions, and respond to situations in meaningful ways.

*   Emotions can be both positive and negative, influencing our mood, behavior, and relationships.
*   Understanding emotions can help us develop emotional intelligence, which is essential for effective communication, conflict resolution, and personal growth.

**The 6 Types of Basic Emotions**

Research has identified six basic emotions that are universally experienced across cultures:

1.  Happiness
2.  Sadness
3.  Fear
4.  Disgust
5.  Anger
6.  Surprise

These emotions serve as the foundation for more complex emotional experiences and play a crucial role in shaping our thoughts, behaviors, and relationships.

**Emotional Intelligence**

Emotional intelligence (EI) refers to the ability to perceive, control, and evaluate emotions. It involves understanding oneself and others, recognizing emotional cues, and developing effective strategies for managing emotions.

*   Emotional intelligence can be developed through practice, self-awareness, and mindfulness.
*   Developing emotional intelligence can improve relationships, communication, and overall well-being.

**The Emotion Wheel**

The emotion wheel is a classification system introduced by psychologist Robert Plutchik. It helps individuals understand and label their emotions, promoting emotional literacy and awareness.

*   The emotion wheel consists of eight primary colors, each representing a different emotion.
*   Understanding the emotion wheel can help individuals develop self-awareness, recognize emotional cues, and improve relationships.

**Healthy Coping Skills**

Developing healthy coping skills is essential for managing uncomfortable emotions. This includes:

1.  Mindfulness practices
2.  Exercise and physical activity
3.  Creative expression (art, music, writing)
4.  Social support networks
5.  Emotional regulation techniques (deep breathing, meditation)

By cultivating these skills, individuals can develop resilience, improve emotional well-being, and navigate life's challenges with greater ease.

**Frequently Asked Questions**

*   How many emotions are there?
    While researchers have identified six basic emotions, there are over 27 different categories of emotions.
*   What causes emotions?
    Emotions are influenced by a network of interconnected structures in the brain that make up the limbic system.
*   Can we control our emotions?
    Yes, individuals can develop self-regulation skills through mindfulness and emotional intelligence.

Emotions play a vital role in shaping who we are and how we interact with the world around us. If left untreated, childhood depression can lead to long-term consequences, including lower academic achievement, poor social relationships, and increased risk of substance abuse.

**Understanding Childhood Depression**

Childhood depression is a complex condition that can manifest differently in each child. It's essential to understand the warning signs and seek professional help if you suspect your child may be struggling with depression.

*   Changes in appetite or sleep patterns
*   Withdrawal from social activities or friends
*   Irritability, mood swings, or sadness
*   Difficulty concentrating or paying attention
*   Loss of interest in activities they once enjoyed

**Recognizing Warning Signs**

Warning signs of childhood depression can be subtle and may not always be immediately apparent. Look for changes in behavior, mood, or physical symptoms that may indicate your child is struggling with depression.

1.  **Mood swings**: Your child may become easily irritable, anxious, or sad.
2.  **Changes in appetite**: They may experience a decrease or increase in appetite, leading to weight loss or gain.
3.  **Sleep disturbances**: Your child may have difficulty falling asleep, staying asleep, or experiencing excessive sleepiness.
4.  **Loss of interest**: They may lose interest in activities they once enjoyed, such as hobbies, sports, or spending time with friends.

**Seeking Professional Help**

If you suspect your child is struggling with depression, consult with a mental health professional or their pediatrician. A qualified therapist can assess your child's symptoms and provide guidance on treatment options.

*   Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT): Helps children identify and change negative thought patterns.
*   Family therapy: Involves working with the entire family to improve communication, problem-solving skills, and relationships.
*   Medications: May be prescribed to help regulate mood and alleviate symptoms of depression. 

**Addressing Suicidal Thoughts**

If your child expresses suicidal thoughts or intentions, seek immediate professional help. A mental health professional can provide guidance on how to address these feelings safely.

1.  **Create a safety plan**: Develop a plan with your child that includes steps they can take to stay safe when feeling overwhelmed.
2.  **Encourage open communication**: Talk openly and honestly about their feelings, and listen attentively to what they have to say.
3.  **Seek professional help**: Consult with a mental health professional for guidance on how to address suicidal thoughts safely.

*   **Model healthy behaviors**: Demonstrate positive coping mechanisms and stress management techniques to help your child learn from you.
*   **Seek support for yourself**: Don't forget to prioritize your own mental health and seek support if needed.

While childhood depression can be challenging to prevent, there are steps you can take to reduce the risk of developing this condition.

**Causes and Risk Factors**

While the exact causes of childhood depression are not yet fully understood, several factors may contribute to its development.

*   **Genetic predisposition**: Children with a family history of depression or other mental health conditions may be more susceptible.
*   **Environmental factors**: Exposure to trauma, abuse, neglect, or bullying can increase the risk of developing childhood depression.
*   **Brain chemistry**: Imbalances in neurotransmitters, such as serotonin and dopamine, may contribute to depressive symptoms.

**What is Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder?**

Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is a mental health condition characterized by recurring thoughts (obsessions) and repetitive behaviors (compulsions). An estimated 2.3% of U.S. adults experience OCD at some point in their lives, with the condition being more common in women than men.

**Causes of OCD**

The exact causes of OCD are not completely understood, but a combination of factors likely play a role. Research suggests that increased activity in certain areas of the brain is linked to a higher risk for OCD. Environmental factors such as sudden life changes, relationship troubles, abuse, illness, and stress may also contribute to the onset of the condition.

**Symptoms of OCD**

Common symptoms of OCD include:

*   Recurring thoughts (obsessions) that create distress
*   Repetitive behaviors (compulsions) aimed at reducing anxiety caused by obsessions
*   Significant interference with daily life

**Types of OCD**

While the DSM-5 does not list specific subtypes, research suggests that OCD can present in a few different forms, including:

*   Hoarding disorder
*   Ordering and symmetry
*   Contamination and cleaning
*   Checking
*   Obsessive thoughts without compulsions

**Treatment Options**

OCD is typically treated with medication and psychotherapy. Effective treatments include:

*   Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT)
*   Exposure and response prevention (ERP) therapy
*   Deep brain stimulation
*   Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS)

**Living With OCD**

Common issues faced by individuals living with OCD include:

*   Intrusive thoughts
*   Compulsive behaviors
*   Interference with daily life

content:
About This Article Table of Contents What Is Psychosis? Types Symptoms Causes Diagnosis Treatments Coping What Is Psychosis? Psychosis is a loss of contact with reality, typically including delusions (false ideas about what is taking place or who you are) and hallucinations (seeing or hearing things that aren't there). It impacts the way that the brain processes information. When experiencing psychosis, people may hear, see, feel, or believe things that are not real.1 Psychosis is a symptom associated with a number of health conditions including the manic phase of bipolar I disorder, as well as schizophrenia, post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), and schizoaffective disorder. Other conditions where psychosis may be present include postpartum psychosis and depressive episodes. About 7 in every 1000 people experience psychosis at some time in their lives.2 Postpartum Psychosis Can Be Fatal If Left Untreated-Here's What to Know 

**What Is Psychosis?**

Psychosis is a loss of contact with reality, typically including delusions (false ideas about what is taking place or who you are) and hallucinations (seeing or hearing things that aren't there). It impacts the way that the brain processes information. When experiencing psychosis, people may hear, see, feel, or believe things that are not real.

1.  Psychosis is a symptom associated with a number of health conditions including the manic phase of bipolar I disorder, as well as schizophrenia, post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), and schizoaffective disorder.
2.  Other conditions where psychosis may be present include postpartum psychosis and depressive episodes.
3.  About 7 in every 1000 people experience psychosis at some time in their lives.

**Types**

Some forms of psychosis are brought on by a specific condition, such as:

1.  Bipolar disorder, which may involve manic episodes that can lead to psychosis
2.  Brief psychotic disorder, which is a short and sudden onset of psychosis, often in response to a stressful situation, that usually lasts less than a month
3.  Delusional disorder, which is marked by an inability to distinguish between what is real and imagined
4.  Drug-induced psychosis, which may occur when a person is withdrawing from a drug such as alcohol or methamphetamine
5.  Postpartum psychosis, a severe form of postpartum depression that, while relatively rare, requires emergency medical intervention
6.  Schizoaffective disorder, which involves symptoms of a mood disorder and schizophrenia
7.  Schizophrenia, which is characterized by a range of psychotic symptoms
8.  Schizophreniform disorder, a short-term type of schizophrenia
9.  Severe depression can also cause people to experience symptoms of psychosis

Psychosis can also be induced by illness or medication or caused by a medical condition, such as a brain tumor, brain disease, or brain infection.

**Symptoms**

Psychosis in itself is a symptom of another problem, not its own illness. Symptoms of psychosis include:

1.  Delusions
2.  Disorganized, scattered thinking and speech
3.  Hallucinations
4.  Thoughts that jump around from subject to subject

If you think you or someone you love is experiencing psychosis, it's essential to seek medical treatment immediately.

**Causes**

The exact causes of psychosis are not entirely clear and each person's experience may be different.

1.  Physical problems that can cause psychosis include:
    *   Alcohol and certain illicit drugs, including methamphetamine
    *   Brain cysts or tumors
    *   Certain prescription drugs, particularly steroids and stimulants
    *   Certain types of epilepsy
    *   Dementia
    *   HIV
    *   Parkinson's disease
    *   Stroke
2.  Psychosis can also be caused by a mental health condition such as schizophrenia, schizoaffective disorder, bipolar disorder, or depression.
3.  People are more likely to develop psychosis if they also have a close family member who has a psychotic disorder.

**Diagnosis**

Psychosis is a symptom of another health condition, not a diagnosis in and of itself. In order to determine what might be causing psychosis, a doctor will perform a physical and collect a medical history. They will also ask questions about the symptoms including its severity and duration. They will also want to know about any other symptoms that you might be experiencing.

In some cases, your doctor may perform special tests in order to rule out medical conditions that may be causing your psychosis. Once your doctor has diagnosed what is causing your symptoms, they can recommend treatments that are best suited to your particular situation.

**Treatments**

Treating psychosis depends on the cause.

1.  Hospitalization may be necessary.
2.  If you have a disorder that involves psychosis, starting or changing antipsychotics may also be helpful in keeping psychotic symptoms and episodes at bay.
3.  Typical Antipsychotics:
    *   Haldol (haloperidol)
    *   Loxitane (loxapine)
    *   Navane (thiothixene)
    *   Prolixin (fluphenazine)
    *   Stelazine (trifluoperazine)
    *   Thorazine (chlorpromazine)
    *   Trilafon (perphenazine)
4.  Atypical Antipsychotics:
    *   Abilify (aripiprazole)
    *   Clozaril (clozapine)
    *   Fanapt (iloperidone)
    *   Geodon (ziprasidone)
    *   Invega (paliperidone)
    *   Latuda (lurasidone)
    *   Rexulti (brexipiprazole)
    *   Risperdal (risperidone)
    *   Saphris (asenapine maleate)
    *   Seroquel (quetiapine)
    *   Vraylar (cariprazine)
    *   Zyprexa (olanzapine)

**Coping**

If you are experiencing symptoms of psychosis, it is essential to seek help immediately. There are also things that you can do along with treatment that may help you better cope:

1.  Find social support.
2.  Try looking for local support groups in your area or find an online group.
3.  Understand your triggers.
4.  Have a plan.

If you or a loved one are struggling with psychosis, contact the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA) National Helpline at 1-800-662-4357 for information on support and treatment facilities in your area. **8 Stigma Busters Shifting the Way We Think About Depression**

**Overview**
With the rise of social media as an educational resource for various topics, even mental health professionals are utilizing these platforms to create digestible content packed with timely mental health tips and insights.

*   Many public figures are currently influencing how people think about depression and debunking stigmas associated with this condition
*   This article spotlights eight public figures who are openly discussing depression and destigmatizing conversations related to a diagnosis

**Peace Amadi**

1.  Dr. Peace Amadi, PsyD is a psychology professor, author, speaker, and coach to many
2.  She provides media content on multiple outlets, such as TedTalk and ABC News
3.  Peace connects psychological concepts with spirituality, incorporating the Christian faith and biblical passages into her practices
4.  She advocates for addressing certain stigmas often associated with depression in the Black community and Christian religion

**Rachel Havekost**

1.  Rachel Havekost is a best-selling author of Where The River Flows, a memoir about her healing journey battling an eating disorder and divorce
2.  She possesses a master's degree in mental health counseling but decided on a career in healing writing
3.  Aside from being an author, she also offers classes, workshops, and consultations tailored to guide individuals on their path to healing

**Imani Tutt**

1.  Imani Tutt, MFT-LP, is a certified marriage and family therapist-lp and an intuitive coach who offers group and individual coaching sessions and courses
2.  She helps individuals overcome heartbreak and heal past wounds, guiding them in their journey of self-discovery and self-awareness
3.  Experiencing her own journey to self-love, she has created a safe space to openly address the trauma associated with relationships and love

**Mai Abe**

1.  Mai Abe is the founder of Creative Vibes Music Therapy in the San Francisco Bay Area
2.  She uses music as a tool to help increase self-esteem and confidence in most clients who suffer from mental health issues, substance use, and neuropsychiatric disorders
3.  As an Asian American woman, she grew up in spaces where mental health was rarely spoken about

**Dr. Kojo Sarto**

1.  Dr. Kojo Sarto is a Black man certified in psychotherapy
2.  He makes strides within the community of Black men silenced by stigmatization and discrimination
3.  In his book You Already Won, Kojo discusses the journey that led him to become a health professional

**Dr. Judith Joseph**

1.  Dr. Judith Joseph is a board-certified psychiatrist who offers services to children, adolescents, young adults, and adults
2.  She utilizes social media to educate the public about evidence-based treatments and diagnoses
3.  With over 100K followers on both Instagram and TikTok, she supplies credible content that informs individuals of the truths surrounding psychiatric care

**Logan Cohen**

1.  Logan Cohen is a certified therapist and fitness coach with over 1M followers on TikTok
2.  He discusses problems surrounding toxic masculinity, stigmas associated with men and mental healthcare, and cues that may not be considered when assessing mental health issues in men
3.  In a TikTok video regarding healthy masculinity, he expresses the importance of vulnerability and acceptance of emotions

**Jacqueline Garcia**

1.  Jacqueline Garcia is an advocate for mental health in the Latinx community
2.  As a certified therapist with expertise in trauma, she informs individuals about the trauma related to suppressing mental health issues in this community
3.  She created a video that focuses explicitly on the different stigmas associated with mental illness in the Latinx community

**A Word From Verywell**
Every one of these public figures has developed a large following on social media, and their content reaches thousands of people, for some, millions.

*   Too often, social media is the only place some people run across mental health information because they do not know where or how to seek it; many don't even realize they need it
*   The mental health experts mentioned in this article may help steer individuals in the right direction to seek the help they need
